Title: QDA
Summary: Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA) is a dimensionality reduction and classification technique used to transform high-dimensional data into a lower-dimensional space while maximizing class separability. Unlike Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), QDA allows for the modeling of class-specific covariance structures, accommodating more complex relationships between features and classes.

Advantages.Flexible Covariance Modeling: QDA can capture complex relationships between features and classes by modeling distinct covariance structures for each class, making it suitable for data with non-linear separability.
Advantages.Effective in Non-Linear Cases: QDA is well-suited for situations where the decision boundaries between classes are non-linear, as it can better adapt to such scenarios compared to LDA.
Advantages.Feature Selection: QDA automatically selects a subset of features that contribute most to class separation, enhancing model simplicity and interpretability.
Advantages.Well-Separated Classes: In cases where classes are well-separated, QDA can provide more accurate and distinct boundaries compared to LDA.

Disadvantages.Data Requirement: QDA typically requires a relatively large number of samples per class to accurately estimate class-specific covariance matrices. In cases of imbalanced data, it can lead to suboptimal results.
Disadvantages.Sensitivity to Outliers: QDA can be sensitive to outliers, as they may affect the estimation of covariance matrices and, consequently, class boundaries.
Disadvantages.Computationally Intensive: The estimation and computation of class-specific covariance matrices can be computationally intensive, especially for large datasets or high-dimensional data.
Disadvantages.Supervised Nature: QDA is a supervised technique, requiring class labels for dimensionality reduction, which limits its applicability to unsupervised problems.
